description: Comprehensive allowlist of legitimate marketing and email service provider domains with subdomain patterns

subdomain_patterns.pattern_notes: These prefixes are commonly used by legitimate ESPs and companies for click tracking, open tracking, and email delivery. They typically appear as subdomains like 'click.example.com' or 'track.example.com'.

email_service_providers.description: Major email service providers and their domains

SendGrid.notes: Twilio SendGrid is one of the largest ESPs. Uses custom branded link patterns like 'clicks.yourdomain.com' or default sendgrid.net domains.
SendGrid.legitimacy: Highly trusted ESP used by major brands worldwide

Mailgun.legitimacy: Trusted ESP especially for developers and technical teams

Mailchimp.notes: One of the most popular marketing automation platforms
Mailchimp.legitimacy: Widely used by small to medium businesses for email marketing

Mandrill.notes: Mailchimp's transactional email service. Custom tracking domains are subdomains pointing to mandrillapp.com
Mandrill.legitimacy: Trusted transactional email service owned by Mailchimp

SparkPost.legitimacy: Major ESP used for high-volume email delivery

Amazon SES.legitimacy: AWS service used by many enterprises

Postmark.notes: Transactional email service focused on deliverability

Mailjet.notes: Email service provider with marketing and transactional capabilities

Brevo.notes: Formerly Sendinblue, offers marketing and transactional email

Customer.io.notes: Automated messaging platform with custom link tracking domains

MailerSend.notes: Transactional email service with clean APIs

marketing_automation_platforms.description: Marketing automation platforms with email tracking capabilities

HubSpot.notes: All-in-one marketing, sales, and CRM platform. Uses custom tracking subdomains for click tracking.
HubSpot.legitimacy: Major marketing automation platform used by thousands of companies

Marketo.notes: Adobe Marketo Engage - enterprise marketing automation. Uses branded tracking domains.
Marketo.legitimacy: Enterprise-grade platform, part of Adobe Experience Cloud

Pardot.notes: Salesforce Marketing Cloud Account Engagement (formerly Pardot). B2B marketing automation.
Pardot.legitimacy: Salesforce product, widely trusted in B2B marketing

Klaviyo.notes: E-commerce focused marketing automation. Recommends 'trk.' prefix for custom tracking domains.

Braze.notes: Customer engagement platform. Requires subdomains for sending and click tracking domains for each subdomain.

crm_platforms.description: CRM platforms with email tracking capabilities

Salesforce.notes: Salesforce Marketing Cloud and Sales Cloud email tracking

Zoho.notes: Zoho CRM and ZeptoMail transactional email service. Uses tracking subdomains for email tracking.
Zoho.legitimacy: Major CRM and business software provider

ecommerce_platforms.description: E-commerce platforms and their email notification domains

Shopify.notes: E-commerce platform. Stores often use custom email subdomains like 'email.brand.com' for campaigns.
Shopify.legitimacy: Leading e-commerce platform with millions of merchants

BigCommerce.notes: E-commerce platform with email notification capabilities

WooCommerce.notes: WordPress e-commerce plugin, emails sent through WordPress or ESP integrations
WooCommerce.legitimacy: Most popular e-commerce plugin for WordPress

travel_hospitality.description: Hotel and travel booking confirmation domains

Expedia Group.notes: Travel booking platform emails. Uses @expediagroup.com for corporate communications.
Expedia Group.caution: Phishing campaigns often impersonate Expedia. Verify sender addresses carefully.

Marriott.notes: Hotel chain email notifications. Note: email-marriott.com is legitimate but best practice would be notification.marriott.com subdomain.
Marriott.caution: Past data breach led to domain reputation issues. Verify emails carefully.

financial_services.description: Financial services and payment processor email domains

PayPal.caution: Frequently impersonated in phishing attacks. Verify sender addresses carefully.

Stripe.notes: Payment processing platform. Supports custom email domains for businesses.

Venmo.legitimacy: Popular P2P payment service (owned by PayPal)

Google Analytics.notes: Web analytics service. GA4 tracks subdomains automatically with same Measurement ID. Note: google.com is too broad to include in allowlist.

Adobe Analytics.notes: Adobe Experience Cloud analytics. Uses demdex.net for cross-domain tracking cookies. Note: adobe.com is too broad to include in allowlist.

other_legitimate_services.description: Other commonly encountered legitimate email services

Zendesk.notes: Customer service platform with email notifications

custom_tracking_domains.description: How to validate custom tracking domains
rules: Custom tracking domains should be subdomains of legitimate company domains (e.g., click.company.com)
The subdomain should point to a known ESP via CNAME records
Common legitimate prefixes: click, clicks, track, trk, link, links, email, go, mail
Verify the parent domain belongs to the expected company
Check for HTTPS/SSL certificates for the tracking domain
Legitimate tracking domains inherit reputation from parent domain

red_flags.description: Warning signs that a tracking domain might be suspicious
flags: Misspelled company names in domain (e.g., amazom.com instead of amazon.com)
Random character subdomains that don't match company branding
Domains using hyphenated versions of brands (pay-pal.com)
Multiple subdomains that don't follow standard patterns

best_practices.description: Best practices for evaluating email tracking domains
practices: Always verify the full domain, not just the subdomain
Check DNS records (CNAME should point to known ESP)
Verify SPF, DKIM, and DMARC records
Be extra cautious with financial services and travel booking emails
When in doubt, visit the company website directly rather than clicking email links
Use domain reputation services to check historical behavior

phishing_considerations.notes: Even if a domain appears in this allowlist, always verify the complete domain path and use additional authentication methods (DKIM, SPF, DMARC) to confirm legitimacy. Phishers may compromise legitimate ESPs or use similar-looking domains.

sources.note: This allowlist was compiled from research on legitimate email service providers, marketing automation platforms, and industry best practices as of February 2026.
